Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerated as it states that the federal government will have more revenue than any year in the history of the country without providing enough evidence to support this statement.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific data or evidence to back up the assertion that the federal government will have record revenues.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that measuring federal revenues as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) would give a different impression and may not support the claim that this year's revenue is the highest in history.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it includes an incorrect statement about deficits in the past 60 years, which undermines the credibility of the overall claim.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there have been deficits for 51 out of the past 60 years, rather than the 55 stated by the speaker.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that measuring federal revenues in raw dollars is the best or only way to determine the record revenue, without considering other factors such as inflation or the size of the economy.
